title: 109_s1084
content: The "End Child Poverty Act" may be cited as the official title of this Act. The findings section highlights key information related to child poverty. Congress finds that nearly 1 in 5 children in the US live below the poverty line, with many coming from working families. Poor children are more likely to suffer from health and educational challenges compared to non-poor children. Nearly 1 in 5 children in the United States live below the poverty line, experiencing serious deprivations such as lack of food, utilities, and adequate housing. Eighteen percent of children are hungry or at risk of hunger due to poverty, leading to health and educational challenges. Child poverty has increased by 1.3 million since 2000. Child poverty in the United States has risen significantly since 2000, with a higher rate compared to other industrialized nations. African-American and Latino children are disproportionately affected, with one third of African-American children and nearly a third of Latino children living in poverty. Great Britain has successfully lifted 2 million children out of poverty and has committed to ending child poverty by 2020. Congress is urged to address poverty as a moral issue. The Act aims to cut child poverty in half within a decade and eliminate it entirely. A Child Poverty Elimination Board will develop a plan to achieve this goal. The Child Poverty Elimination Board, established by the Act, consists of 12 members appointed by Senate and House leaders. The Child Poverty Elimination Board, established by the Act, consists of 12 members appointed by Senate and House leaders based on expertise in child poverty issues. Members are appointed by the Speaker of the House of Representatives, the majority leader of the Senate, the minority leader of the House of Representatives, and the minority leader of the Senate. The Child Poverty Elimination Board consists of 12 members appointed for life. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Board elects a chairperson and vice chairperson. Meetings are held within 30 days of all members being appointed. The Board develops a plan to cut child poverty in half within a decade. The Child Poverty Elimination Board aims to cut child poverty in half within a decade and eliminate it entirely. A report with recommendations for fund allocations will be submitted to relevant committees and the President within a year of the Act's enactment. The Board has the power to hold hearings, gather evidence, and take testimony as needed. The Child Poverty Elimination Board has the authority to gather evidence, take testimony, administer oaths, and access information from federal agencies to fulfill its duties under the Act. It can also request facilities and services from federal agencies and seek personnel from other agencies if needed. The Child Poverty Elimination Board can request personnel from other agencies to serve as Executive Director or assist in duties without affecting their civil service status. The chairperson can accept voluntary services from Board members. Board members serve without compensation but are allowed reasonable travel expenses. According to section 5703 of title 5, United States Code, Board members must adhere to specific guidelines when carrying out their duties. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE AND IMPLEMENTATION OF PLAN. The President must issue a plan within 90 days of receiving the Board's report to cut child poverty in half within a decade and eliminate it entirely. The plan will allocate funds from the Child Poverty Elimination Trust Fund. The President's plan must align with the Board's plan unless modifications are deemed more effective for poverty elimination. Implementation of the plan must be ensured within 90 days of issuance. The President must ensure the implementation of the plan issued to cut child poverty in half within a decade and work with Congress to secure funding for it. SEC. 6. IMPOSITION OF INDIVIDUAL INCOME TAX SURCHARGE TO FUND CHILD POVERTY ELIMINATION FUND. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to impose an additional income tax on individuals with adjusted gross income exceeding certain threshold amounts. The tax increase is 1 percent of the income exceeding $1,000,000 for joint returns and $500,000 for other returns. This tax does not apply to estates and trusts. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 imposes an additional income tax on individuals with adjusted gross income exceeding certain thresholds. The tax increase is 1 percent of the income exceeding $1,000,000 for joint returns and $500,000 for other returns. This tax does not apply to estates or trusts. Additionally, a Child Poverty Elimination Fund is established under Subchapter A of chapter 98 of the Internal Revenue Code. The Child Poverty Elimination Trust Fund is established under Subchapter A of chapter 98 of the Internal Revenue Code. The Child Poverty Elimination Trust Fund is created in the Treasury of the United States to eliminate child poverty through federal programs funded by a surtax imposed under section 1(j). The table of sections for subchapter A of chapter 98 of the Code is amended by adding a conforming amendment. The amendments establish the Child Poverty Elimination Trust Fund, effective for taxable years after December 31, 2005. The amendment is not considered a change in tax rate under section 15 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
